sections.title: Understanding Sum and Difference
sections.content: The bar model helps you visualize problems where you need to find totals or differences between quantities.

sections.title: Key Concepts:
items: SUM: When you add two or more parts to find the total
DIFFERENCE: When you subtract to find how much more or less

sections.title: Why they work:

items.text: If you draw a 'Total' bar and a 'Part' bar, you visually see the gap is the other 'Part' (Subtraction).

sections.title: Model Method: Unequal Sharing/Ratios
sections.description: Learn to solve ratio problems using bar models.

sections.title: Understanding Ratios
sections.content: Ratios show the relationship between quantities. Use bar models to visualize and solve ratio problems.

sections.title: Key Concepts:
items: Ratio shows comparison: 2:3 means for every 2 of one, there are 3 of another
Use equal-sized units in bar models
Find the value of 1 unit first, then multiply

sections.title: Example 1: Simple Ratio
sections.description: Tom and Jerry share 35 marbles in the ratio 3:4. How many marbles does each boy get?
sections.detailedDescription: A ratio checks how many 'shares' or 'units' each person gets. Here, for every 3 marbles Tom gets, Jerry gets 4. This means there are 7 equal shares in total.
detailedSteps: Tom has 3 units, Jerry has 4 units.
Total units = 3 + 4 = 7 units.
We know 7 units represent 35 marbles.
To find 1 unit, we divide: 35 Ã· 7 = 5 marbles.
Tom's share = 3 units x 5 = 15 marbles.
Jerry's share = 4 units x 5 = 20 marbles.

sections.title: Example 2: Money Sharing
sections.description: Amy and Ben share $60 in the ratio 2:3. How much does Amy get?
sections.detailedDescription: When sharing money in a ratio, we first find the total number of parts (units) mentioned in the ratio. Then we split the total money into that many equal parts.
detailedSteps: The ratio is 2:3, so Total Units = 2 + 3 = 5.
The total money is $60, which corresponds to these 5 units.
Value of 1 Unit = $60 Ã· 5 = $12.
Amy has 2 units, so she gets 2 x $12 = $24.

sections.title: Multiples and Factors / LCM & GCF
sections.description: Master finding LCM and GCF to solve real-world problems.

sections.title: LCM and GCF Explained
sections.content: LCM (Least Common Multiple) is the smallest number that is a multiple of two or more numbers. GCF (Greatest Common Factor) is the largest number that divides evenly into two or more numbers.

sections.title: When to Use:
items: LCM: Finding when events happen together (schedules, patterns)
GCF: Dividing things into equal groups, simplifying fractions

sections.title: Example: Finding LCM
sections.description: Bus A arrives every 12 minutes. Bus B arrives every 18 minutes. If both arrive at 8:00 AM, when will they next arrive together?
sections.detailedDescription: To find when two events repeating at different speeds will happen together, we need the Least Common Multiple (LCM). This is the first number that both time intervals can divide into evenly.
detailedSteps: Bus A intervals: 12, 24, 36, 48, ...
Bus B intervals: 18, 36, 54, ...
We see that 36 is the first number that appears in both lists.
So, the LCM is 36 minutes.
They will meet 36 minutes after 8:00 AM, which is 8:36 AM.

sections.title: Example: Finding GCF
sections.description: A teacher has 24 pencils and 36 erasers. What is the largest number of identical gift bags she can make so that no items are left over?
sections.detailedDescription: When we want to split different items into identical groups with nothing left over, we look for the Greatest Common Factor (GCF). This is the largest number that can divide both totals.
detailedSteps: The largest number in both lists is 12.
So, she can make 12 identical gift bags.

sections.title: Example 3: Three-Part Ratio
sections.description: A ribbon 120 cm long is cut into 3 pieces in the ratio 2:3:5. Find the length of the longest piece.
sections.detailedDescription: Ratios can compare more than two things. Here we have 3 parts: A, B, and C. The method is the same: find total units and the value of 1 unit.
detailedSteps: The ratio is 2:3:5. Add the parts: 2 + 3 + 5 = 10 total units.
The total length is 120 cm, which represents these 10 units.
Value of 1 unit = 120 Ã· 10 = 12 cm.
The longest piece corresponds to the largest number in the ratio, which is 5.
Length of longest piece = 5 units x 12 cm = 60 cm.

sections.title: Example 4: Ratio with Difference
sections.description: The ratio of Sara's money to Tom's money is 5:3. Sara has $24 more than Tom. How much money does Sara have?
sections.detailedDescription: Sometimes we are given the DIFFERENCE between quantities instead of the total. We must find the difference in 'units' first, then equate that to the value given.
detailedSteps: Sara has 5 units, Tom has 3 units.
The difference in units = 5 - 3 = 2 units.
The problem says Sara has $24 more, so 2 units = $24.
Value of 1 unit = $24 Ã· 2 = $12.
We need to find Sara's money (5 units).

sections.title: Example 5: LCM Word Problem
sections.description: Three lights blink at intervals of 4 seconds, 6 seconds, and 8 seconds. If they all blink together now, after how many seconds will they blink together again?
sections.detailedDescription: This is a classic LCM problem involving synchronization. We need to find a time interval that is a multiple of 4, 6, and 8.
detailedSteps: List multiples of 4: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24...
List multiples of 6: 6, 12, 18, 24...
List multiples of 8: 8, 16, 24...
The first number common to all three lists is 24.
So, the lights will blink together again after 24 seconds.

sections.title: Tutorial: Finding Perimeter
sections.description: Perimeter is the total distance around the outside of a shape.

sections.title: Example 1: Basic Rectangle
items: Problem: Find the perimeter of a rectangle with length 8cm and breadth 5cm.
Step 1: Identify the formula. Perimeter = (Length + Breadth) Ã— 2
Step 2: Add the Length and Breadth. 8 + 5 = 13
Step 3: Multiply by 2. 13 Ã— 2 = 26
Answer: The perimeter is 26 cm.

sections.title: Example 2: Square
items: Problem: Find the perimeter of a square with side length 6cm.
Step 1: A square has 4 equal sides.
Step 2: Formula: Perimeter = Side Ã— 4
Step 3: Multiply: 6 Ã— 4 = 24
Answer: The perimeter is 24 cm.

sections.title: Example 3: Composite Figure
items: Problem: Find the perimeter of an L-shaped figure made of two rectangles.
Step 1: Trace the outer boundary with your finger.
Step 2: Add up the lengths of ALL outer sides.
Step 3: Be careful! Do not include internal lines.
Answer: Sum of all outer sides.

sections.description: Area is the amount of space inside a shape.

sections.title: Example 1: Area of Rectangle
items: Problem: Find the area of a garden 10m long and 4m wide.
Step 1: Formula: Area = Length Ã— Breadth
Step 2: Multiply: 10 Ã— 4 = 40
Answer: The area is 40 mÂ².

sections.title: Example 2: Area of Square
items: Problem: Find the area of a square tile with side 7cm.
Step 1: Formula: Area = Side Ã— Side
Step 2: Multiply: 7 Ã— 7 = 49
Answer: The area is 49 cmÂ².

sections.title: Example 3: Working Backwards
items: Problem: The area of a rectangle is 24 cmÂ². Its length is 6 cm. Find its breadth.
Step 1: Recall Area = Length Ã— Breadth
Step 2: Use division. Breadth = Area Ã· Length
Answer: The breadth is 4 cm.

sections.title: Why & When to Use Bar Models
sections.content: Bar models are a visual tool to solve word problems. They are the bridge between reading a sentence and writing an equation.

sections.title: When to use them:
items: When the problem involves calculating a 'Total' or a 'Difference'.
When you see phrases like 'more than', 'less than', '3 times as many', or 'gave away'.
In Ratio and Fraction problems where you need to find the value of '1 unit'.

sections.title: Why they work:
items: They prevent mistakes. By drawing the bars, you can instantly see if you need to add or subtract.

items.text: If you draw a 'Total' bar and a 'Part' bar, you visually see the gap is the other 'Part' (Subtraction).
If you draw two parts making a whole, you see it is Addition.

sections.title: 1.1 Order of Operations (BODMAS)
sections.description: Calculate the value of the expression: 20 + 40 Ã· (5 + 3) x 2.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: 20 + 40 Ã· (5 + 3) x 2

Let's break this down step-by-step using the BODMAS rule. Just like a recipe, we must follow the order exactly to get the right answer.

1. **B**rackets: Always solve what is inside the brackets first.
2. **O**rders: Powers or Square roots (None here).
3. **D**ivision & **M**ultiplication: Do these next, from left to right.
4. **A**ddition & **S**ubtraction: Do these last, from left to right.
detailedSteps:
Step 1: Look for Brackets (). We have (5 + 3). Solve that first.
   5 + 3 = 8.
   Now the equation is: 20 + 40 Ã· 8 x 2

Step 2: Look for Division or Multiplication. We do them from left to right.
   First is Division: 40 Ã· 8 = 5.
   Now the equation is: 20 + 5 x 2

Step 3: Still looking for Division or Multiplication. We have 5 x 2.
   5 x 2 = 10.
   Now the equation is: 20 + 10

Step 4: Finally, do Addition or Subtraction.
   20 + 10 = 30.
   The final answer is 30.

sections.title: 1.2 Distributive Law (Smart Calculation)
sections.description: Use the distributive law to calculate the product of 48 and 25 using mental math strategies.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Calculate 48 x 25 using mental math.

The Distributive Law lets us break difficult numbers into easier ones. Here, multiplying by 25 is hard, but multiplying by 100 and dividing by 4 is easy because 25 is a quarter of 100.
detailedSteps: Step 1: Recognize that 25 is a 'special number'. It is exactly 100 divided by 4.
Step 2: Rewrite the problem. Instead of 48 x 25, think of it as 48 x (100 Ã· 4).
Step 3: Divide 48 by 4 first used mental math. 48 Ã· 4 = 12.
Step 4: Now multiply the result by 100. 12 x 100 = 1200.

sections.title: 1.3 Rounding & Estimation
sections.description: Estimate the product of 3986 and 5.1 by rounding each number to its nearest simple value first.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Estimate 3986 x 5.1

Estimation is about finding an answer that is 'close enough' quickly. We round each number to its nearest simple value (like thousands or ones) to make the math easy.
detailedSteps: Step 1: Look at the first number, 3986. It is very close to 4000. So we round it to 4000.
Step 2: Look at the second number, 5.1. The .1 is very small, so we round it down to 5.
Step 3: Multiply your new simple numbers. 4000 x 5.
Step 4: Calculate: 4 x 5 = 20, and adds the three zeros. Result is 20,000.

sections.title: 1.4 Multi-Step Word Problem
sections.description: A factory produces 5000 pens, which are packed into boxes of 20. Each box costs $1 to produce, and each pen is sold for $2. Calculate the total profit made from selling all the pens.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: A factory produces 5000 pens (packed in boxes of 20, $1/box to produce). Pens sell for $2 each. What is the total profit?

Profit = Revenue - Cost. We need to calculate the Cost and Revenue separately first.
steps: Wait, careful with units. Let's simplify.
detailedSteps:
Step 1: Find the Cost. The pens are in boxes of 20. How many boxes do we need for 5000 pens?
   5000 Ã· 20 = 250 boxes.

Step 2: Calculate cost of boxes. Each box is $1.
   250 boxes x $1 = $250 (Total Cost).

Step 3: Find the Revenue (Sales). Each pen is sold for $2.
   5000 pens x $2 = $10,000 (Total Revenue).

Step 4: Calculate Profit. Subtract Cost from Revenue.
   $10,000 - $250 = $9,750.

sections.title: 1.5 Place Value Logic
sections.description: Determine the place value of the digit 7 in the number 7,654,321.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Find the value of the digit 7 in 7,654,321.

Place value tells us how much a digit is worth based on where it sits in the number. As we move left, each place is 10 times bigger.
detailedSteps: Step 1: Identify the digit we want. It is the '7' at the very front.
Step 2: Count how many digits are behind it. There are 6 digits (6,5,4,3,2,1).
Step 3: Replace all those digits with zeros to find the value.
Step 4: The 7 followed by 6 zeros is 7,000,000 (Seven Million).

sections.title: 2.1 Mixed Number Multiplication
sections.description: Calculate the product of the mixed numbers 2 1/2 and 1 1/3.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Calculate 2 1/2 x 1 1/3

Okay, so multiplying Mixed Numbers (like 2 1/2) can be tricky because of the whole number part. But don't worry! We have a secret weapon: 

**Improper Fractions!** (Those value-packed fractions where the top is bigger than the bottom).

If we turn our mixed numbers into improper fractions first, the multiplication becomes super easy. Let's try it together step-by-step!
detailedSteps:
Step 1: First, let's transform 2 1/2. 
   Imagine 2 whole pizzas cut into halves. That's 4 halves. Plus the 1/2 we already have... that makes 5 halves! So, 5/2.

Step 2: Now for 1 1/3.
   One whole pizza cut into thirds is 3 slices. Add the extra 1/3... that's 4 thirds! So, 4/3.

Step 3: Now the easy part! multiplied the tops together.
   5 x 4 = 20.

Step 4: Multiply the bottoms together.
   2 x 3 = 6. 
   So we have 20/6.

Step 5: Clean up time! How many 6s fit into 20?
   6, 12, 18. That's 3 times! (3 wholes).
   We have 2 left over (20-18=2). So 3 and 2/6.
   We can make 2/6 simpler by dividing top and bottom by 2 -> 1/3.
   Final Answer: 3 1/3. You did it! ðŸŽ‰

sections.description: Determine how many cups of size 1/4 liter are needed to completely fill a 3-liter jug.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: How many 1/4 liter cups fill a 3 liter jug?

When dividing by a fraction, we use the rule 'Keep-Change-Flip'. We keep the first number, change Divide to Multiply, and Flip the second fraction upside down.
detailedSteps: Step 1: Write equation: 3 Ã· 1/4.
Step 2: 'Keep' the 3.
Step 3: 'Change' Ã· to x.
Step 4: 'Flip' 1/4 to 4/1 (which is just 4).
Step 5: Solve: 3 x 4 = 12 cups.

sections.title: 2A.3 Decimal Multiplication
sections.description: Calculate the product of the decimals 0.3 and 0.4.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Calculate 0.3 x 0.4

The secret to multiplying decimals is to ignore the dots first. Just multiply the whole numbers, then put the dots back in at the end.
detailedSteps: Step 1: Pretend the decimals aren't there. Treat 0.3 as 3 and 0.4 as 4.
Step 2: Multiply: 3 x 4 = 12.

Step 3: Count decimal places in the question. 
   0.3 has ONE decimal place.
   0.4 has ONE decimal place.
   Total = 2 decimal places.

Step 4: Place the decimal point in the answer '12'. Start from the right and jump left 2 times. 
   12 -> 1.2 -> .12 
   Add a zero in front: 0.12.

sections.title: 2B.1 Percentage of a Quantity
sections.description: In a group of 200 people, 40% are children. Calculate the number of people in the group who are adults.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: In a group of 200 people, 40% are children. How many are NOT children?

Percentage means 'out of 100'. 40% means 40 out of every 100. If 40% are children, then the rest (100% - 40% = 60%) must be adults.
steps: Method 1: 40% are children, so 60% are adults.
detailedSteps:
Step 1: Find percentage of adults. 
   Total is 100%. Children is 40%. 
   Adults = 100% - 40% = 60%.

Step 2: Calculate 60% of 200. 
   Write 60% as a fraction: 60/100.

Step 3: Multiply by total (200). 
   (60/100) x 200.

Step 4: Cancel zeros. 100 goes into 200 exactly 2 times. 
   So we just calculate 60 x 2 = 120.

sections.title: 2B.2 Percentage Increase
sections.description: The original price of an item is $50. If the price is increased by 10%, calculate the new price.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: A $50 item has its price increased by 10%. What is the new price?

When a price increases, we find the extra amount (the increase) and ADD it to the original price.
detailedSteps: Step 1: Convert 10% to a decimal or fraction. 10% = 0.10 or 1/10.

Step 2: Find the increase amount. 
   10% of $50 = $5.

Step 3: Add this increase to the original price. 
   Original ($50) + Increase ($5).
Step 4: Final Price = $55.

sections.title: 2B.3 Profit Percentage
sections.description: A shopkeeper buys a toy for $50 and sells it for $60. Calculate his percentage profit.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: A shopkeeper buys a toy for $50 and sells it for $60. What is the profit %?

Profit is the extra money made. Percentage Profit compares that profit to the ORIGINAL cost.
detailedSteps:
Step 1: Find the Profit. 
   Selling Price ($60) - Cost Price ($50) = $10 Profit.

Step 2: Set up the fraction. 
   Profit / Original Cost = 10 / 50.

Step 3: Convert to percentage. 
   (10 / 50) x 100% = 0.2 x 100% = 20%.

sections.title: 2B.4 Loss Percentage
sections.description: A book was bought for $20 and sold for $15. Calculate the percentage loss incurred.
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Bought for $20, sold for $15. Find the Loss %.

Loss happens when you sell for LESS than you bought. We compare the loss to the ORIGINAL cost.
detailedSteps:
Step 1: Find the Loss. 
   Cost ($20) - Selling Price ($15) = $5 Loss.

Step 2: Set up fraction. 
   Loss / Original Cost = 5 / 20.

Step 3: Convert to percentage. 
   (5 / 20) = 1/4 = 25%.

sections.title: 2B.5 Discount Percentage

sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Marked price $80, sold for $60. Find discount %.

Discount is the amount taken OFF the marked price. We compare it to the ORIGINAL marked price.
detailedSteps:
Step 1: Find the Discount amount. 
   Marked ($80) - Selling ($60) = $20 off.

Step 2: Set up fraction based on Marked Price. 
   Discount / Marked = 20 / 80.

Step 3: Convert to percentage. 
   20 / 80 = 1/4 = 25%.

sections.title: 3.1 Finding Total from Ratio

Problem: Flour to sugar ratio is 5:2. Total weight is 700g. How much is sugar?

Ratios tell us how to share things in 'units'. Add the units together to find the total, then figure out what 1 unit equals.

sections.title: 3.2 Missing Term
sections.detailedDescription:
Problem: Find the missing number: 2:5 = 6:?

Whatever you do to one side, do to the other! Find the multiplier by comparing the known numbers.

sections.title: 3.4 Three-Part Ratio

Problem: A:B = 2:3 and B:C = 3:5. Find A:B:C.

We need a 'bridge' to connect the ratios. The bridge is the common element (B).
steps: The 'bridge' is B. Is B the same in both? Yes (it is 3).

steps: Juice is 1 unit. Water is 4 units.

Problem: In isosceles triangle ABC (AB=AC), Angle A = 40Â°. Find Angle B.

steps: Since AB=AC, Angle B and C are equal.

sections.title: 4.3 Volume of Cuboid
sections.description: A tank is 10cm x 10cm x 5cm. How many liters of water can it hold?

Problem: A tank is 10cm x 10cm x 5cm. How many liters of water can it hold?

Volume = Length x Breadth x Height. Remember: 1000 cmÂ³ = 1 Liter.

Problem: Find the perimeter of a composite shape.

Perimeter is the total distance AROUND the outside of the shape. Be careful not to count accurate lines that are 'inside' the shape where they join.
steps: Do NOT include the shared inner side.

sections.content: Primary 6 uses letters like 'a' and 'x' to represent unknown numbers, and expects you to work with patterns and expressions. This bridge section gives you a head start so P6 feels smooth and manageable!

sections.title: B1. What is a Variable?
sections.description:
? + 3 = 10
Think of a mystery box: What number is hiding in the box? We can use a letter instead: n + 3 = 10. Find n.
sections.detailedDescription:
A variable is a letter that stands for a number we don't know yet. Instead of writing '?', mathematicians use letters like n, x, or a.

Think of it like a name tag for a mystery number. Once you figure out what number it is, you've 'solved' it!
detailedSteps: The letter 'n' represents our mystery number.
We need to find what number, when we add 3 to it, gives us 10.
To find n, we do the opposite of adding 3: we subtract 3.
Check: 7 + 3 = 10. âœ“ Correct!

sections.title: B2. More Variables Practice
sections.description: There are y sweets in a bag. After eating 5, there are 12 left. Write this as an equation and find y.
sections.detailedDescription:
We can use a variable to represent something we don't know in a real-life situation. Here, 'y' represents the total number of sweets.

The key skill is translating the English sentence into a math equation.
detailedSteps: Let y = total sweets at the start.
'After eating 5' means we subtract: y - 5.
'There are 12 left' tells us the result: y - 5 = 12.
To solve, do the opposite of subtracting 5: add 5 to both sides.
Check: 17 - 5 = 12. âœ“ Correct!

sections.title: B3. Number Patterns
sections.description: Look at this pattern: 3, 7, 11, 15, ___. What is the rule? What comes next?
sections.detailedDescription:
Number patterns follow a rule. Finding the rule helps you predict what comes next â€” this is the foundation of algebra!

Look at what happens between each number to spot the pattern.
detailedSteps: Find the difference between consecutive numbers.
3 â†’ 7: difference is 4.
7 â†’ 11: difference is 4.
11 â†’ 15: difference is 4.
The rule is: 'add 4 each time' (or 'start at 3, add 4').
The next number is 15 + 4 = 19.
As a formula: the nth term = 3 + 4Ã—(n-1). But for now, just spot the pattern!

sections.title: B4. Input-Output Tables
sections.description: A machine follows a rule. Input: 2â†’7, 3â†’10, 5â†’16. What is the rule? What output does input 10 give?
sections.detailedDescription:
Input-output tables are like a magic machine: you put a number in, the machine does something to it, and a different number comes out.

Finding the rule is like cracking a code â€” it's the same skill you'll use with formulas in P6!
detailedSteps: Look at input 2 â†’ output 7. What operation turns 2 into 7?
2 Ã— 3 = 6 (close but not 7). 2 Ã— 3 + 1 = 7 âœ“
Test with input 3: 3 Ã— 3 + 1 = 10 âœ“
Test with input 5: 5 Ã— 3 + 1 = 16 âœ“
The rule is: multiply by 3, then add 1 (or 3n + 1).
For input 10: 10 Ã— 3 + 1 = 31.

sections.title: B5. LCM (Lowest Common Multiple)
sections.description: Find the LCM of 4 and 6. This skill is essential for combining ratios in P6!
sections.detailedDescription:
The LCM is the smallest number that both numbers divide into evenly. In P6, you'll need LCM to combine two ratios (like A:B and B:C) into one.

There are two methods: listing multiples, or using prime factorization.
detailedSteps: Method 1: List multiples until you find a common one.
Multiples of 6: 6, 12, 18, 24...
The first number that appears in BOTH lists is 12.
Why P6 needs this: If ratio A:B = 2:3 and B:C = 4:5, you make B the same using LCM(3,4) = 12.

sections.title: B6. HCF (Highest Common Factor)
sections.description: Find the HCF of 12 and 18. HCF helps simplify fractions and ratios!
sections.detailedDescription:
The HCF is the largest number that divides evenly into both numbers. You use HCF to simplify fractions (like 12/18) and to simplify ratios.

Factors are numbers that divide evenly into a number with no remainder.
detailedSteps: Find all factors of 12: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12.
Find all factors of 18: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18.
Common factors (in both lists): 1, 2, 3, 6.
The HIGHEST (largest) common factor is 6.
Use: To simplify 12/18, divide both by HCF: 12Ã·6 / 18Ã·6 = 2/3.

sections.title: B7. Words to Math
sections.description: Translate into math: 'A number x is multiplied by 4, then 3 is subtracted. The result is 17.' Write the equation and find x.
sections.detailedDescription:
In P6, you'll need to turn word problems into algebra equations. The trick is to translate each part of the sentence one at a time.

Key words: 'multiplied by' = Ã—, 'subtracted' = âˆ’, 'added' = +, 'divided by' = Ã·, 'is' / 'the result is' = equals sign (=).
detailedSteps: 'A number x' â€” our variable is x.
'is multiplied by 4' â€” that gives us 4 Ã— x, written as 4x.
'then 3 is subtracted' â€” we get 4x - 3.
'The result is 17' â€” this means equals: 4x - 3 = 17.
Solve: Add 3 to both sides: 4x = 20.
Divide both sides by 4: x = 5.

sections.title: B8. Writing Expressions
sections.description: Sarah has s stickers. Tom has 3 times as many stickers as Sarah, plus 2 more. Write an expression for Tom's stickers.
sections.detailedDescription:
An expression is different from an equation: it doesn't have an equals sign. It just describes a quantity using a variable.

In P6, you'll write expressions like these all the time to set up word problems.
detailedSteps: Sarah's stickers = s (given).
'3 times as many as Sarah' means 3 Ã— s, which we write as 3s.
'plus 2 more' means we add 2: 3s + 2.
Tom's stickers = 3s + 2.
If Sarah has 4 stickers (s=4): Tom has 3(4) + 2 = 14 stickers.
This is called an algebraic expression.

sections.title: 1.1 Algebraic Expressions
sections.description: Simplify the following algebraic expression: 2a + 3 + 5a - 1.
sections.detailedDescription: To simplify an algebraic expression, we must 'group like terms'. This means we look for terms that have the same variable (like 'a') and combine them. Numbers without variables are also combined separately.
detailedSteps: Identify the terms with 'a': 2a and 5a.
Add their coefficients: 2 + 5 = 7. So, 2a + 5a = 7a.
Identify the constant numbers: 3 and -1.
Perform the subtraction: 3 - 1 = 2.
Combine the results to get the final expression: 7a + 2.

sections.title: 1.2 Substitution
sections.description: Given that m = 6, evaluate the expression 2m/3 + 4.
sections.detailedDescription: Substitution involves replacing a variable letter (like 'm') with its given number value. Always follow the order of operations (BODMAS) after substitution.
detailedSteps: Substitute m with 6 in the expression: (2 x 6) / 3 + 4.
Multiply the top part first: 2 x 6 = 12.
Divide by 3: 12 / 3 = 4.
Finally, add 4: 4 + 4 = 8.

sections.title: 1.3 Ratio: Repeated Identity
sections.description: The ratio of A to B is 2:3, and the ratio of B to C is 4:5. Determine the combined ratio A:B:C.
steps: B is common. LCM of 3 and 4 is 12.
sections.detailedDescription: When we have two separate ratios with a common item (like B), we need to make B the same number in both ratios to combine them. We use the Lowest Common Multiple (LCM) for this.
detailedSteps: In A:B (2:3), B is 3. In B:C (4:5), B is 4.
Find the LCM of 3 and 4, which is 12.
To make B=12 in the first ratio, multiply by 4: A:B becomes 8:12.
To make B=12 in the second ratio, multiply by 3: B:C becomes 12:15.
Now that B is 12 in both, we can combine them: A:B:C = 8:12:15.

sections.title: 1.4 Word Problem (Algebra)
sections.description: Ali has $x. Ben has $4 more than Ali. If the total amount of money they have is $20, determine the value of x.
sections.detailedDescription: We can use algebra to solve word problems by defining a variable (x) for an unknown value and building an equation.
detailedSteps: Let Ali's money be x.
Since Ben has $4 more, Ben's money is (x + 4).
The total is Ali + Ben, so the equation is: x + (x + 4) = 20.
Combine like terms: 2x + 4 = 20.
Subtract 4 from both sides: 2x = 16.
Divide by 2: x = 8. So Ali has $8.

sections.title: 1.5 Ratio of Areas
sections.description: Two squares have side lengths of 2 cm and 3 cm, respectively. Calculate the ratio of their areas.
sections.detailedDescription: The ratio of areas is NOT the same as the ratio of side lengths. If you square the side lengths, you get the areas.
detailedSteps: Side length ratio is 2:3.
Area of first square = 2 x 2 = 4.
Area of second square = 3 x 3 = 9.
Therefore, the ratio of their areas is 4:9.

sections.title: 2.1 Basic Speed
sections.description: Calculate the speed of a runner who covers 100m in 10s.
sections.detailedDescription: Speed tells us how fast something is moving. It is the distance traveled in 1 unit of time (like 1 second or 1 hour).
detailedSteps: We use the formula: Speed = Distance Ã· Time.
Here, Distance = 100m, Time = 10s.
The unit is meters per second (m/s).

sections.title: 2.2 Finding Distance
sections.description: A car travels at a constant speed of 60 km/h for 3 hours. Calculate the total distance covered.
sections.detailedDescription: To find the distance covering during a trip, we multiply the speed (how fast) by the time (how long).
detailedSteps: Formula: Distance = Speed Ã— Time.
Speed = 60 km/h.
Time = 3 hours.
Distance = 60 Ã— 3 = 180 km.

sections.title: 2.3 Average Speed
sections.description: A driver travels 100 km in 2 hours, and then another 100 km in 3 hours. Calculate the average speed for the entire journey.
sections.detailedDescription: Average Speed is NOT the average of the two speeds. It is the Total Distance divided by the Total Time of the entire journey.
detailedSteps: Total Distance = 100km + 100km = 200km.
Total Time = 2h + 3h = 5h.
Average Speed = Total Distance Ã· Total Time.
Average Speed = 200 Ã· 5 = 40 km/h.

sections.title: 2.4 Meeting Time
sections.description: Town A and Town B are 200 km apart. Two cars start from these towns and move towards each other at speeds of 60 km/h and 40 km/h, respectively. Determine how long it takes for them to meet.
sections.detailedDescription: When two objects move towards each other, they close the gap faster. Their 'combined' or 'relative' speed is the sum of their individual speeds.
detailedSteps: Object A Speed: 60 km/h. Object B Speed: 40 km/h.
Combined Speed = 60 + 40 = 100 km/h.
Total gap to close = 200km.
Time = Distance Ã· Speed = 200 Ã· 100 = 2 hours.

sections.title: 2.5 Catching Up
sections.description: Person A starts walking at 10 km/h. One hour later, Person B starts chasing at 20 km/h. Calculate the time it takes for Person B to catch up to Person A.
steps: Time to close gap = 10km / 10 km/h = 1 hour.
sections.detailedDescription: When one object chases another, the gap closes at the 'difference' of their speeds. The faster object must make up the head start distance.
detailedSteps: A starts 1 hour early at 10km/h, so Head Start Distance = 10km.
B is faster by: 20 - 10 = 10 km/h (Relative Speed).
This means B gains 10km on A every hour.
Time to catch up = Head Start Distance Ã· Relative Speed.
Time = 10 Ã· 10 = 1 hour.

sections.title: 4.1 Net of an Open Cube

steps: An open cube lacks the top face, so we modify the count.
sections.detailedDescription: A standard cube is composed of 6 identical square faces (Top, Bottom, Front, Back, Left, Right). When a cube is described as 'without a lid' or 'open', it implies the top face is missing. Therefore, we must subtract 1 from the total count of faces.

2. Analyze the condition 'without a lid': This means the top face is removed.

sections.title: 4.2 Pie Chart Reading
sections.description: A pie chart represents a total population of 200 people. If the 'Blue' sector occupies 50% of the chart, calculate the number of people represented by this sector.
steps: The Blue sector represents 50% of the total.
sections.detailedDescription: A Pie Chart illustrates how a whole quantity is divided into parts. The entire circle represents 100% (or 360Â°). To determine the value of a specific sector, we multiply the total quantity by the percentage occupied by that sector.
detailedSteps: 1. Identify the percentage of the sector: The Blue sector is 50%.
2. Identify the total quantity: The total population is 200 people.
3. Set up the calculation: Amount = Percentage Ã— Total.
4. Solve: 0.50 Ã— 200 = 100. Alternatively, since 50% is half, half of 200 is 100.

sections.title: 4.3 Volume of Liquid
sections.description: A tank is currently half full containing 500ml of water. Calculate the total capacity of the tank in liters.
steps: Represent the current volume as 1/2 of the total capacity.
sections.detailedDescription: When given a fractional part of a total capacity, we can determine the full capacity by multiplying by the reciprocal of the fraction. Here, since half the tank is 500ml, the full tank must be twice that amount.
detailedSteps: 1. Establish the relationship: 1/2 of Capacity = 500ml.
2. Solve for the full capacity: Multiply 500ml by 2 to get 1000ml.
3. Convert the unit to liters as requested: Since 1000 milliliters equals 1 Liter, the total capacity is 1 Liter.

sections.title: 4.4 Average in Pie Charts
sections.description: A pie chart is divided into three sectors with values 10, 20, and 30. Calculate the mean value of these sectors.
steps: Calculate the sum of the values: 10 + 20 + 30 = 60.
sections.detailedDescription: The 'Mean' (or Average) is a measure of central tendency. It is calculated by summing all individual values and dividing by the count of those values.
detailedSteps: 1. Sum the values of the sectors: 10 + 20 + 30 = 60.
2. Determine the total count of items: There are 3 sectors.
3. Apply the formula: Mean = Sum Ã· Count.
4. Calculation: 60 Ã· 3 = 20.

sections.title: 4.5 Probability (Simple)
sections.description: A standard six-sided die is rolled once. Determine the probability of obtaining a number greater than 4.
sections.detailedDescription: Probability quantifies the likelihood of an event occurring. It is defined as the ratio of the number of favorable outcomes to the total number of possible outcomes.
detailedSteps: 1. List all possible outcomes of rolling a die: {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. Total = 6.
2. List the favorable outcomes (greater than 4): {5, 6}. Count = 2.
3. Form the fraction: Probability = Favorable / Total = 2/6.
4. Simplify the fraction: 2/6 simplifies to 1/3.

sections.title: 8.1 Gauss Summation
sections.detailedDescription: When summing a long list of sequential numbers, we can pair the first and last numbers. Each pair has the same sum.
detailedSteps: There are 100 numbers, so there are 50 pairs.
Total Sum = 50 pairs Ã— 101 = 5050.

sections.title: 8.2 Ones Digit Pattern
sections.description: Find the ones digit of 3^50.
sections.detailedDescription: The last digit of powers of a number often repeats in a cycle. We find the pattern cycle to predict the digit for any large power.
detailedSteps: Next is 3^5=243 (ends in 3). The pattern repeats: 3, 9, 7, 1.
The cycle length is 4.
Divide exponent by cycle: 50 Ã· 4 = 12 remainder 2.
Remainder 2 means it is the 2nd number in the pattern: 9.

sections.title: 8.3 Assumption Method
sections.description: 20 animals (Chickens & Cows). 56 legs. How many Cows?
sections.detailedDescription: The Assumption Method helps solve problems with two variables. We assume ALL items are of one type, calculate the total, find the error, and adjust.
detailedSteps: 1. Assume all 20 animals are Chickens (2 legs).
Total legs = 20 Ã— 2 = 40 legs.
2. Compare with actual legs: 56 - 40 = 16 legs shortage.
3. Each Cow has 2 more legs than a Chicken.
4. Number of Cows = Shortage Ã· Difference = 16 Ã· 2 = 8 Cows.

sections.title: 8.4 Working Backwards
sections.description: Spent $10. Then spent 1/2 of remaining. Left with $5. Initial?
sections.detailedDescription: For problems where a series of events happens, start from the FINAL result and reverse every step (Opposite operation) to find the start.
detailedSteps: Final amount: $5.
Step 2 reversed: 'Spent 1/2' means he had double. $5 Ã— 2 = $10.
Step 1 reversed: 'Spent $10'. So add $10 back. $10 + $10 = $20.
Initial Amount = $20.

sections.title: 8.5 Excess and Shortage
sections.description: Give 3 sweets, left 4. Give 4 sweets, short 2. How many kids?
sections.detailedDescription: When distributing items creates a shortage in one case and excess in another, the Total Difference divided by the Difference Per Unit gives the number of units (kids).
detailedSteps: Case 1 (Give 3): Left 4 (Need 4 less).
Case 2 (Give 4): Short 2 (Need 2 more).
Total Gap = 4 + 2 = 6 sweets.
Difference per kid = 4 - 3 = 1 sweet.
Number of kids = 6 sweets gap Ã· 1 sweet difference = 6 kids.

sections.title: 8.6 Supposition Logic
sections.description: True/False test. 10 Qs. +5 correct, -2 wrong. Score 29. How many correct?
sections.detailedDescription: This is a variation of the Assumption Method. Getting a question wrong loses the points you WOULD have got, PLUS the penalty subtracted.
detailedSteps: 1. Assume all 10 correct: 10 Ã— 5 = 50 points.
2. Actual score: 29. Gap = 50 - 29 = 21 points.
3. 'Cost' of switching Correct(+5) to Wrong(-2) is 5 - (-2) = 7 points.
4. Number of Wrongs = 21 Ã· 7 = 3 questions.
5. Number Correct = 10 - 3 = 7 questions.

detailedSteps: 1. Calculate number of spaces (gaps): 100m Ã· 10m = 10 gaps.
2. For a line, Trees = Gaps + 1.

We need the 103rd letter.
103 Ã· 5 = 20 groups with Remainder 3.
Ideally it ends on 'E' (5th), but we have 3 remainder.

Remaining spots: 1st, 2nd.

Remaining spot: 1st -> Must be B.
Order: 1. B, 2. A, 3. C.

sections.title: 9.1 Working Together (River)

sections.detailedDescription: To find a fake (light) coin efficiently, divide the pile into 3 equal groups. A balance scale gives us maximal info by comparing two groups.
detailedSteps: 1. Split 9 coins into groups A, B, C (3 coins each).
2. Weigh A vs B. Step 1 complete.
- If Balanced: Fake is in C.
- If Unbalanced: Fake is in the lighter side (say A).
3. Take the 3 suspect coins. Weigh 1 vs 1. Step 2 complete.
- If Balanced: It's the 3rd one.
- If Unbalanced: It's the lighter one.

sections.title: 9.3 Water Jugs
sections.description: Have 5L and 3L jugs. Measure exactly 4L.

detailedSteps: 1. Fill 5L jug. Pour into 3L jug until full.
(5L jug now holds 2L).
2. Empty the 3L jug. Pour the 2L from the big jug into the 3L jug.
(3L jug now holds 2L, has 1L space).
3. Fill 5L jug again. Pour carefully into 3L jug to fill it.
(You pour exactly 1L because that's the space left).
4. 5L - 1L = 4L. Success!

detailedSteps: Strategy Walk: 20km Ã· 5km/h = 4 hours. (Simple).
Strategy Run: 10km/h means 30mins covers 5km.
Cycle: Run 30m (5km) + Rest 10m = 40 mins total for 5km.
We need 20km, so 4 cycles.
Total Time = 4 Ã— 40 mins = 160 mins = 2 hours 40 mins.
Running is faster by 1 hour 20 mins.

sections.title: 9.5 Truth Paradox
sections.description: 'This sentence is false.' True or False?
steps: If True, it says it is False -> Contradiction.
If False, it says it is True -> Contradiction.
sections.detailedDescription: A paradox is a logical statement that cannot be true or false without contradicting itself. This is the famous 'Liar Paradox'.
detailedSteps: Assume the sentence is TRUE: It says it is false. -> Contradiction.
Assume the sentence is FALSE: It says it is false, so it must be true. -> Contradiction.
Therefore, the statement has no truth value.

sections.title: 9.6 Sudoku Logic

sections.detailedDescription: Sudoku puzzles work on the rule that every number must appear exactly once in every row, column, and box.
detailedSteps: Rule: Numbers 1, 2, 3, 4 must appear in the row.
Current Row: [1, 2, x, 4].
Missing number: We have 1, 2, 4. The only missing digit is 3.
So x = 3.

sections.title: 9.7 Minimum Moves (Towers)

sections.detailedDescription: The Towers of Hanoi is a puzzle where you must move a stack of disks. The Key Rule: No value can be placed on top of a smaller value.
detailedSteps: Goal: Move 2 disks from A to C.
1. Move Small disk A -> B.
2. Move Big disk A -> C.
3. Move Small disk B -> C.
Result: Stack is now on C. Moves = 3.

sections.title: 9.8 Birthday Paradox
sections.description: 23 people in room. Chance of shared birthday?
steps: Logic: Many pairs to compare (23x22/2 = 253 pairs).
sections.detailedDescription: The Birthday Paradox shows how human intuition fails with probability. In a group of just 23 people, there is a >50% chance two share a birthday.
detailedSteps: We don't look for a match with YOU, but a match between ANY two people.
Number of possible pairs with 23 people is (23 Ã— 22) Ã· 2 = 253 pairs.
With 253 chances for a match, the probability rises very fast.
At 23 people, probability is approx 50.7%.

sections.title: 9.10 Monty Hall
sections.description: 3 Doors. Pick 1. Host opens goat door. Switch?
steps: Yes. Switching doubles win chance from 1/3 to 2/3.
sections.detailedDescription: The Monty Hall problem is a counter-intuitive probability puzzle. Always switch doors!
detailedSteps: 1. You pick Door 1. Chance is 1/3.
2. Host opens Door 3 (Goat). The 'uncropped' probability of 2/3 is now concentrated on Door 2.
3. If you stay, you win only if you were right initially (1/3).
4. If you switch, you win if you were WRONG initially (2/3).
Switching doubles your variance.

sections.detailedDescription:
This is a classic 'Combined Rate' problem.

Key Concept:
We add RATES, not times.
Rate M = 1/36 tank/min.
Rate N = 1/28 tank/min.

sections.title: Ex 4. Man-Hours
sections.description: If 5 men can build a wall in 9 days, how long would it take 3 men to build the same wall?
sections.detailedDescription:
Key Concept: 'Man-Days'.
Total Work = Men x Days.
This total work stays constant.
steps: Total Work = 5 men x 9 days = 45 man-days.
Days needed = Total Work / Men = 45 / 3 = 15 days.

sections.title: 5.1 Mixture Problem
sections.description: Mix 200g of 10% salt solution with 300g of 20% salt solution. What is the new concentration?
sections.detailedDescription: When mixing two solutions, we must find the TOTAL amount of solute (salt) and divide it by the TOTAL amount of solution (mixture).
detailedSteps: Sol 1: 10% of 200g = 20g salt.
Sol 2: 20% of 300g = 60g salt.
Total Salt = 20g + 60g = 80g.
Total Mixture = 200g + 300g = 500g.

sections.title: 5.2 Concentration Change
sections.description: A 500ml solution is 20% acid. How much water must be added to make it 10% acid?
sections.detailedDescription: Adding water does NOT change the amount of acid (solute). We use the constant amount of acid to find the new total volume required for the lower concentration.
detailedSteps: 1. Find current acid amount: 20% of 500ml = 100ml acid.
2. This 100ml needs to be 10% of the new mixture.
3. So, 10% -> 100ml. Then 100% -> 1000ml (New Total).
4. Existing liquid is 500ml. Water needed = New Total - Old Total.
5. Water = 1000ml - 500ml = 500ml.

sections.title: 5.3 Work Rate (Individual)
sections.description: A takes 4 hours to paint a wall. Rate?
steps: Rate = 1 Job / 4 Hours = 1/4 job per hour.
sections.detailedDescription: Work rate is having 1 job divided by the time taken. It tells us what fraction of the job is completed in 1 hour.
detailedSteps: Job Size = 1.
Time Taken = 4 hours.
Rate of Work = 1 Ã· 4 = 1/4 of the job per hour.

sections.title: 5.4 Combined Work Rate
sections.description: A takes 4 hours. B takes 6 hours. Together?
sections.detailedDescription: To find how fast people work together, we ADD their individual rates (not their times).
detailedSteps: Rate A = 1/4 job/hr. Rate B = 1/6 job/hr.
Combined Rate = 1/4 + 1/6.
Common denominator is 12: 3/12 + 2/12 = 5/12 job/hr.
Time = 1 Job Ã· Total Rate = 1 Ã· (5/12) = 12/5 hours.
12/5 hrs = 2.4 hours.

sections.title: 5.5 Concept of 'Remainder'
sections.description: Spent 50% of money, then 50% of REMAINDER. Total spent?
sections.detailedDescription: Percent of 'Remainder' means percent of what is LEFT, not percent of the total. We must calculate the second spend based on the remaining amount.
detailedSteps: Start with 100%. Spend 50% -> Left with 50%.
Now spend 50% of the REMAINDER (which is 50%).
Calculation: 50/100 Ã— 50% = 25%.
Total Spent = First Spend (50%) + Second Spend (25%) = 75%.

sections.title: 5.6 Internal Transfer (Total Unchanged)
sections.description: A:B = 1:3. A receives 10 from B. New ratio 1:1. Find Total.
steps: Total units in 1:3 is 4. Total units in 1:1 is 2.
LCM of 4 and 2 is 4. Change 1:1 to 2:2.
A goes from 1 to 2 units. Gain 1u = 10.
sections.detailedDescription: When items are transferred internally between A and B, the TOTAL (A+B) remains unchanged. We use this constant total to equate the ratios.
detailedSteps: Initial Ratio A:B = 1:3. Total = 1+3 = 4 units.
Final Ratio A:B = 1:1. Total = 1+1 = 2 units.
Make totals equal: LCM of 4 and 2 is 4.
Multiply Final Ratio by 2 -> 2:2. (Total is now 4).
Compare A: Started at 1 unit, ended at 2 units. Gain = 1 unit.
We know A gained 10. So 1 unit = 10.
Total (4 units) = 4 Ã— 10 = 40.

sections.title: 5.7 One Quantity Unchanged
sections.description: A:B = 2:3. Add 10 to A. New A:B = 4:3. Find Initial A.
sections.detailedDescription: If only A changes, then B must remain the SAME in both ratios. We adjust the ratios to make B's units match.
detailedSteps: Initial A:B = 2:3. (B is 3).
Final A:B = 4:3. (B is 3).
B is already the same (3 units), so we can compare A directly.
A changed from 2 units to 4 units -> Gain of 2 units.
A gained 10. So 2 units = 10 -> 1 unit = 5.
Initial A (2 units) = 2 Ã— 5 = 10.

sections.title: 5.8 Equal Amount Change
sections.description: A:B = 3:4. Both add 10. New 4:5. Find 1 unit.
sections.detailedDescription: If the SAME amount is added to both, the DIFFERENCE between them remains constant. We use the constant difference to match ratios.
detailedSteps: Initial 3:4. Difference = 1 unit.
Final 4:5. Difference = 1 unit.
Since difference is already equal (1), we can compare directly.
3->4 is an increase of 1 unit.
Problem says added 10. So 1 unit = 10.
